channel.title: Eclipse Plugins, Bundles and Products - Eclipse Marketplace

item.title: SAP Commerce Cloud (Hybris) - Developer Toolset Plugin
item.description:
Date Updated: 
Mon, 2019-04-08 03:57
EPAM Systems
Date Created: 
Mon, 2017-02-06 12:53
Submitted by: 
EPAM Systems

Ready to optimize your SAP Commerce Cloud (formerly known as SAP Hybris Commerce) development environment?

EPAM’s SAP Commerce Cloud - Developer Toolset Plugin for Eclipse enables SAP Commerce Cloud code to be imported, manipulated and worked with directly in Eclipse, resulting in enhanced productivity and code quality.

The plugin lets users work with common SAP Commerce Cloud items, such as ImpEx files and flexible search queries, directly within Eclipse. It makes it easy to import and update extensions and their dependencies into the Eclipse workspace.

The plugin offers:

  • A custom impex editing environment with built-in auto-complete that simplifies writing fresh code and ensures proper syntax
  • Easy import of specific SAP Commerce Cloud extensions, along with resolving their dependencies
  • Flexible search editing environment with auto-complete and formatting, also including the ability to execute it right against the remote server and see the result inside your IDE 
  • Quick creation and run-time of simple queries without subqueries or join statements
  • Ability to generate SAP Commerce Cloud-specific classes
  • Ability to run and validate ImpEx on remote servers
  • Solr search console which allows the execution of Solr queries directly from Eclipse
  • SAP Commerce Cloud Log Analyzer, which helps you easily troubleshoot your application in real-time
  • And much more!

Read more about SAP Commerce Cloud Developer Toolset for Eclipse

Watch the overview video about SAP Commerce Cloud Developer Toolset for Eclipse

This plugin has been created by experienced SAP Commerce Cloud developers from EPAM’s SAP Customer Experience (CX) Competency Center, the same team that brought you the #1 SAP Commerce Cloud technical blog, hybrismart.com. This plugin represents the battle-tested lessons of those developers from dozens of SAP Commerce Cloud implementations spanning platform versions (v4.x to current release), global geography, multiple industries and complex solution types (B2C, B2B, B2B2C, PIM/PCM, etc.).  

EPAM is invested in making SAP Commerce Cloud development more efficient and productive. If you have feedback, suggestions or requests, please send them to hybriseclipseplugin@epam.com.

EPAM is an SAP Platinum Partner and has created a long line of SAP Commerce Cloud-centric accelerators, extensions, connectors, microservices and plugins. Interested in getting involved and joining this global team? Learn more at https://www.epam.com/careers/hybris-talent.
item.dc:creator: esystems

item.title: PlantUML plugin
item.description:
Date Updated: 
Mon, 2019-04-08 03:06
Dept. of Computer Science at The Norwegian Univ. of Science and Tech
Date Created: 
Tue, 2019-02-05 06:10
Submitted by: 
Hallvard Traetteberg

The plantuml library implements a DSL and renderer for many UML diagrams (class, sequence, objects, states, activities, …). See http://plantuml.com for more info about the DSL and renderer.

This project integrates plantuml’s functionality into Eclipse, by means of a view that shows a diagram for the currently active editor. The rendered diagram is typically based on explicit DSL code embedded in the editor, or generated from the content of the editor.

We currently support generating diagrams for

  • DSL code embedded in text in any text editor
  • the class in the Java and Class File editors, based on the Eclipse Java model
  • the EClasses in Ecore models in the Ecore editor

There’s also experimental support for generating a diagram for all the Java classes in a Java project (or within one or more Java packages).

Diagram generation is handled by (implementations of) an extension point, so you can customize the process of generating a diagram for other file types or editor content.
item.dc:creator: htraetteb

item.title: MultiProperties
item.description:
Date Updated: 
Sat, 2019-04-06 14:46
skzs
Date Created: 
Tue, 2011-12-13 07:36
Submitted by: 
Krisztián Zsolt Sallai

MultiProperties Editor is an Eclipse plugin for editing multiple key-value based files with similar content. This kind of file format can be Properties for example in Java programming language, which is frequently used for backing a ResourceBundle. However the plugin is not limited to support only Properties files. Instead it stores everything in one XML file, including the list of keys, all of the values, descriptions and meta information. When the editor saves its content into the XML file, it also saves different kind of output files with help of handlers. Since the handlers are used through standard Eclipse extension point, not just the already available handlers can be used. You can also implement your own handler which produces your own output format, for example you can produce SQL files instead of Properties files.
item.dc:creator: mmisingnameioc

item.title: iSphere for RDi 9.5+
item.description:
Date Updated: 
Sat, 2019-04-06 09:15
iSphere Project Team
Date Created: 
Tue, 2017-01-10 16:11
Submitted by: 
Thomas Raddatz

iSphere is an open source plug-in for WDSCi 7.0 and RDi 8.0+. It delivers high quality extensions for WDSC, RDP and RDi to further improve developer productivity.

IBM's current Eclipse based Integrated Development Environment (IDE) is a huge step beyond SEU, but it still lacks features available only on the green screen. That is where the iSphere Project comes into play, filling in those gaps.

Feature list:

  • Binding Directory Editor
  • Data Area Editor
  • User Space Editor
  • Data Queue Viewer
  • Message File Editor
  • Message File Compare Editor
  • Message File Search
  • Source File Search
  • Source Compare/Merge Editor
  • Spooled Files Subsystem
  • Lpex Task Tags
  • Host Object Decorator
  • RSE Filter Manager
  • Message Subsystem and Monitor
  • Job Log Explorer
  • Journal Explorer

iSphere is an Open Source project that is hosted on Source Forge.
item.dc:creator: traddatz

item.title: Microclimate Developer Tools
item.description:
Date Updated: 
Fri, 2019-04-05 16:11
IBM
Date Created: 
Thu, 2018-10-04 13:18
Submitted by: 
Joseph Kim

Use Microclimate Developer Tools for Eclipse to develop your Microclimate projects from within Eclipse. Use the tools to access Microclimate features in the comfort of your IDE.

GitHub Repository • Slack

Features 

  • View all Microclimate projects for a connection including the application and build status
  • Import your Microclimate project into the Eclipse workspace
  • Debug Microprofile/Java EE and Spring applications
  • Set up a debug session in a Chromium based browser for Node.js applications
  • View application and build logs in the Console view
  • Integrate Microclimate validation errors into the Markers view
  • Open a shell session into a Microclimate application container
  • Toggle the project auto build setting and manually initiate project builds
  • Open your application or the application monitor in a browser

How to Use

  • Make sure to uninstall Microclimate Developer Tools Beta if you have it installed
  • Install Microclimate Developer Tools for Eclipse
  • Verify that you have a local instance of Microclimate 18.12 or later running
  • Create a new connection to Microclimate:
    • From the File menu select New > Other > Microclimate > New Microclimate Connection
    • Fill in the Hostname (only localhost is supported) and Port (usually 9090)
    • Click Test connection and then click Finish
  • This should open the Microclimate Explorer view with the connection expanded to show your projects. If it does not open the view then open it manually:
    • From the Window menu select Show View > Other > Microclimate > Microclimate Explorer
    • Click Open
  • Right click on the connection to see the available actions for connections
  • Right click on a project to see the available actions for projects
item.dc:creator: jkim

item.title: WireframeSketcher Wireframing Tool
item.description:
Date Updated: 
Fri, 2019-04-05 10:13
WireframeSketcher
Date Created: 
Mon, 2008-11-03 09:15
Submitted by: 
Peter Severin

WireframeSketcher is a rapid wireframing tool that helps quickly create wireframes, mockups and prototypes for desktop, web and mobile applications. It comes both as a plug-in for any Eclipse IDE and a standalone version. With WireframeSketcher users can quickly gather useful feedback from stakeholders, show off their proposals to clients, share their ideas with fellow developers and in the end build better software. Install the 14 days free trial and test it for yourself.

Some of the top features:

  • Extensive library of built-in controls for any type of UI. Stencils for Android, iPhone, iPad apps and more are available.
  • Hand-drawn look for wireframes. Your stakeholders won't be distracted by little details and you can focus on what’s important. Clean look is also available.
  • Create interactive prototypes. Present your prototypes in full-screen mode and click-through to show how the application or website is supposed work. Export your prototypes to clickable, high-quality PDF, or easily share them online in a few clicks.
  • More than 200 wireframing icons. Icons come in vector format, work at any size, can be colored, rotated, and embedded in any text.
  • Use components to create your own reusable bits. Easy inheritance mechanism lets you modify component's instance without breaking the link to its origin.

Download standalone version from our website: http://wireframesketcher.com/download.html.
item.dc:creator: pseverinqw0

item.title: OpenAPI Studio with Rich OAS3 Editor
item.description:
Date Updated: 
Fri, 2019-04-05 09:15
Remain Software
Date Created: 
Fri, 2019-03-22 10:56
Submitted by: 
Wim Jongman

NEW VERSION April 5 2019!! UNINSTALL YOUR OLD VERSION FIRST!

A full OAS3 spec compliant OpenAPI development environment. It includes a rich editor with API testing, import, export and code generation and contains built-in documentation for all parts of the spec.

The visual editor enables you to inspect and edit your API specification in a human-readable way. No more wading around in JSON or YAML unless you want to.

The editor includes the Swagger UI for integrated API testing.

We use Gravity, our award-winning workflow tool, to support you. Did you find a bug? Do you have a question or an enhancement request? You may sign up to join our growing user base.
item.dc:creator: wjongman

item.title: EGit - Git Integration for Eclipse
item.description:
Date Updated: 
Fri, 2019-04-05 07:01
Eclipse.org
Date Created: 
Fri, 2010-06-18 16:30
Submitted by: 
Chris Aniszczyk

EGit is the Git integration for Eclipse. Git is a distributed versioning system, which means every developer has a full copy of all history of every revision of the code, making queries against the history very fast and versatile. The EGit project is implementing Eclipse tooling on top of the JGit Java implementation of Git. To get started, check out our user guide: http://wiki.eclipse.org/EGit/User_Guide If you have any questions, please use our support forum: http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php?t=thread&frm_id=48
item.dc:creator: caniszczyk

item.title: Eclipse aCute: C# development tools
item.description:
Date Updated: 
Thu, 2019-04-04 18:01
Eclipse aCute contributors
Date Created: 
Thu, 2017-01-26 10:22
Submitted by: 
Mickael Istria

aCute enables C# application development in the Eclipse IDE.

aCute provides a rich C# editor with error reporting, hover, content assist, jump to references... (using OmniSharp) and syntax highlighting (using TextMate grammar).
aCute also integrates various operations of the `dotnet` command-line (New, Run, Test, Publish) as typical Eclipse IDE wizards and workflows.
aCute provide supports debugging for .NET applications
 

aCute is in an Eclipse.org project: https://projects.eclipse.org/projects/tools.acute
item.dc:creator: mistria

item.title: Groovy Development Tools
item.description:
Date Updated: 
Thu, 2019-04-04 13:40
Pivotal
Date Created: 
Wed, 2012-07-04 13:05
Submitted by: 
Andrew Clement

The Groovy Development Tools (GDT) provides Eclipse and Maven support for the Apache Groovy programming language. GDT adds full-featured IDE support including editors, wizards, content assist, debugging, refactoring and searching.

The GDT requires the Eclipse Java Development Tools (JDT) as it builds upon Java/JVM support, including Java interoperability (bi-directional dependencies via joint compilation). If your Eclipse flavor does not include JDT, you must install it first.

GDT does not provide any direct support for Grails. If you want Grails tooling, then please consider Groovy-Grails Tools Suite or spring-projects/grails-ide for your Grails projects.
item.dc:creator: aclement
